content.intro: "Look at the paper!" "Stop fidgeting!" "Focus!" If this is your daily math experience, here's what might be going on.

sections.text: If your child can focus at or near these ranges, that's developmentally normal.

items: **Tired:** Wrong time of day for cognitive work
**Frustrated:** Material too hard, so they check out
**Emotional:** Something else is on their mind
Focus issues across ALL subjects and activities

sections.text: Only a professional can diagnose ADHD. Don't self-diagnose based on focus issues during math alone.
If they can focus for 10 minutes, make practice 10 minutes. Don't fight their biology.
Clear workspace, no TV/music, siblings elsewhere. Make focusing easier.
Wobble cushion, standing desk, fidget toy. Some kids focus BETTER with movement.
5-10 minutes of physical activity before math. Tired muscles = calmer mind.
Gamified apps hold attention better than worksheets. If boredom is the issue, change the format.

items: Strategies don't help after 2-3 months of trying
Problems extend beyond math to daily life

faq.question: How do I get my child evaluated for ADHD?
faq.answer: Start with your pediatrician. They may refer to a psychologist or psychiatrist. School can also do evaluations for educational purposes.

faq.question: If it is ADHD, does that mean medication?
faq.answer: Not necessarily. Treatment can include behavioral strategies, environmental modifications, and therapy. Medication is one option, not the only one.

faq.question: Can kids with ADHD succeed at math?
faq.answer: Absolutely! Many successful people have ADHD. The key is finding strategies that work with their brain, not against it.
